events.description: The release and subsequent downward revision of India's Services Purchasing Managers' Index for January 2026.

facts.fact_text: The HSBC India Services PMI was revised to 58.5 in January 2026 from an initial estimate of 59.3.

evidences.evidence_text: The HSBC India Services PMI was revised lower to 58.5 in January 2026 from a preliminary estimate of 59.3.

facts.fact_text: Input cost inflation for Indian service providers reached a four-month high in January.

evidences.evidence_text: On the price front, input cost inflation accelerated to a four-month high, driven by higher prices for eggs, electronic items, meat, paper, parts, and vegetables.

facts.fact_text: Selling prices in the services sector rose at the fastest rate in three months.

evidences.evidence_text: Meanwhile, selling prices rose at the fastest pace in three months, as firms sought to better balance cost pressures and profitability.

facts.fact_text: Service providers resumed hiring staff due to an increase in new orders.

evidences.evidence_text: Rising new orders prompted service providers to resume hiring staff, though job creation increased only marginally.

claims.claim_text: Business sentiment in the Indian services sector reached a three-month high.
claims.author: HSBC

evidences.evidence_text: Looking ahead, business sentiment improved to a three-month high, supported by optimistic forecasts for efficiency gains, marketing efforts, and new client wins.

claims.claim_text: Firms increased selling prices to protect profitability against rising cost pressures.

evidences.evidence_text: Meanwhile, selling prices rose at the fastest pace in three months, as firms sought to better balance cost pressures and profitability.

evidence.evidence_text: Rising new orders prompted service providers to resume hiring staff
input cost inflation accelerated to a four-month high, driven by higher prices for eggs, electronic items, meat, paper, parts, and vegetables.
the latest figure remained above the December reading of 58.0... supported by faster growth in output and new business.
selling prices rose at the fastest pace in three months, as firms sought to better balance cost pressures and profitability.
